posts.post_content: I have two of these things, but Jund's my second least favourite Shard (after Esper), and the only guy I know with a Jund deck doesn't want them...

Posted By: ElMikkino (2/22/2011 4:33:52 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Not good unless you're using all three. There's plenty of better lands for any combination of 2 of those colors: [Taiga](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Taiga), [Stomping Ground](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stomping Ground), [Overgrown Tomb](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Overgrown Tomb), [Bayou](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bayou), [Badlands](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Badlands), [Bloodcrypt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bloodcrypt). There's plenty of others too.  
In the right deck, the correction is useful enough that the CIPT (or ETBT) is irrelevant, but not always.
posts.html:

posts.post_content: The five tricolor lands of Shards of Alara are direct upgrades of the five tricolor lands of Homelands, with this being an upgrade of [Koskun Keep](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Koskun Keep).
posts.html:
The five tricolor lands of Shards of Alara are direct upgrades of the five tricolor lands of Homelands, with this being an upgrade of Koskun Keep.
Report Abuse  
Posted By: ivorythunder (4/19/2010 7:20:34 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: I would say that I'd still run at least one of these in a deck even with stomping grounds, because it color fixes so well. Play opposite jungle shrine for a more green deck, or crumbling necropolis for more black. The only downside is hopefully not having to play it in your first 1-3 turns when you need mana the first turn you play it.
posts.html:
